A handy class of submodular functions

Jan 1, 2024

In this post, we will show that functions of the form

f(X)=1−∏i∈Ω∖X(1−pi)∏i∈X(1−qi)f(X) = 1 - \prod_{i \in \Omega \setminus X} (1 - p_i) \prod_{i \in X} (1 - q_i)f(X)=1−i∈Ω∖X∏​(1−pi​)i∈X∏​(1−qi​)

are submodular for pi,qi∈[0,1]p_i, q_i \in [0, 1]pi​,qi​∈[0,1] where each pi≤qi,p_i \leq q_i,pi​≤qi​, and examine an application of this small result that demonstrates its practical value.

Background on submodular functions

Given a ground set Ω,\Omega,Ω, a function f:2Ω↦Rf: 2^\Omega \mapsto \mathbb{R}f:2Ω↦R is called submodular if, for any X⊆Y⊆ΩX \subseteq Y \subseteq \OmegaX⊆Y⊆Ω and j∈Ω∖Y,j \in \Omega \setminus Y,j∈Ω∖Y, we have

f(X∪{j})−f(X)≥f(Y∪{j})−f(Y).f(X \cup \{j\}) - f(X) \geq f(Y \cup \{j\}) - f(Y).f(X∪{j})−f(X)≥f(Y∪{j})−f(Y).

In plain language, this says that the marginal value of adding jjj to XXX is greater than when adding it to YYY. Thus, submodularity expresses a form of diminishing marginal returns (for set functions) that is analogous to concavity (for continuous functions).

Submodular functions have a number of desirable traits. A famous result of Nemhauser et al. (1978) holds that when maximizing a monotone1 submodular function over a cardinality constraint, the greedy algorithm that iteratively adds to XXX the element that yields the greatest increase in f(X)f(X)f(X) is 1−1e≈63.2%1 - \frac{1}{e} \approx 63.2\%1−e1​≈63.2% optimal.2 Efficient algorithms that provide the same approximation ratio for more complex constraint structures have also been identified (Badanidiyuru et al. 2014, Chekuri et al. 2014, Kulik et al. 2013). See Vondrák (2017) for an introduction to submodular functions with many examples.

Preliminary interpretation of f(X)f(X)f(X)

The function f(X)f(X)f(X) defined above can be used to model the probability of a parallel system failing when optional repairs are made to its components. For example, suppose there are a dozen roads between our town and the next, and the probabilities of each road being open in the coming winter are given by p1p_1p1​ through p12p_{12}p12​. For each of the roads, we can engage in repairs to increase the availability to qiq_iqi​. Letting XXX denote the set of roads that we repair, the probability of at least one road being open in the winter is one minus the probability that all of them are closed, which is f(X).f(X).f(X).

With this interpretation in mind, we are tempted to give f(X)f(X)f(X) a tortured-but-accurate name such as the “parallel process success probability with quality upgrades” function—but we’ll just stick with f(X)f(X)f(X) for now.

The applicability of f(X)f(X)f(X) in its current form is, admittedly, a bit narrow. The versatility of this functional form shows itself more clearly when we start taking conic combinations—see the examples below.

Monotonicity and submodularity proof

Theorem: f(X)f(X)f(X) as defined above is a monotone submodular function.

Proof: The monotonicity of f(X)f(X)f(X) is clear from the constraints on ppp and qqq: Adding any element jjj to XXX replaces the 1−pj1 - p_j1−pj​ term with the (smaller) 1−qj1 - q_j1−qj​ term, increasing the overall function value.

To prove submodularity, pick any X⊆Y⊆ΩX \subseteq Y \subseteq \OmegaX⊆Y⊆Ω and j∈Ω∖Y.j \in \Omega \setminus Y.j∈Ω∖Y. If pj<1,p_j < 1,pj​<1, we have

f(X∪{j})−f(X)=[1−1−qj1−pj∏i∈Ω∖X(1−pi)∏i∈X(1−qi)]−[1−∏i∈Ω∖X(1−pi)∏i∈X(1−qi)]=−(1−qj1−pj)∏i∈Ω∖X(1−pi)∏i∈X(1−qi)+∏i∈Ω∖X(1−pi)∏i∈X(1−qi)=(1−1−qj1−pj)(1−f(X))≥(1−1−qj1−pj)(1−f(Y))=f(Y∪{j})−f(Y).\begin{aligned} f(X \cup \{j\}) - f(X) &= \biggl[1 - \frac{1 - q_j}{1 - p_j} \prod_{i \in \Omega \setminus X} (1 - p_i) \prod_{i \in X} (1 - q_i) \biggr] - \biggl[1 - \prod_{i \in \Omega \setminus X} (1 - p_i) \prod_{i \in X} (1 - q_i) \biggr] \\ &= - \biggl(\frac{1 - q_j}{1 - p_j}\biggr) \prod_{i \in \Omega \setminus X} (1 - p_i) \prod_{i \in X} (1 - q_i) + \prod_{i \in \Omega \setminus X} (1 - p_i) \prod_{i \in X} (1 - q_i) \\ &= \biggl(1 - \frac{1 - q_j}{1 - p_j}\biggr) \Bigl(1 - f(X)\Bigr) \\ &\geq \biggl(1 - \frac{1 - q_j}{1 - p_j}\biggr) \Bigl(1 - f(Y)\Bigr) \\ &= f(Y \cup \{j\}) - f(Y). \end{aligned}f(X∪{j})−f(X)​=[1−1−pj​1−qj​​i∈Ω∖X∏​(1−pi​)i∈X∏​(1−qi​)]−[1−i∈Ω∖X∏​(1−pi​)i∈X∏​(1−qi​)]=−(1−pj​1−qj​​)i∈Ω∖X∏​(1−pi​)i∈X∏​(1−qi​)+i∈Ω∖X∏​(1−pi​)i∈X∏​(1−qi​)=(1−1−pj​1−qj​​)(1−f(X))≥(1−1−pj​1−qj​​)(1−f(Y))=f(Y∪{j})−f(Y).​

The penultimate inequality follows from monotonicity, and the final equality is just applying the first three steps in reverse, with YYY instead of X.X.X.

In the pj=1p_j = 1pj​=1 case, f(X∪{j})=1f(X \cup \{j\}) = 1f(X∪{j})=1 for any XXX and the inequality collapses to −f(X)≥−f(Y),- f(X) \geq - f(Y),−f(X)≥−f(Y), which is just monotonicity. ◼

Application: Optimal scrum velocity, aka the mmm-dimensional Zeno walk

Let’s examine a plausible(ish) application of this functional form.

The Zeno walk: Consider a Zeno walk between an arbitrary origin and destination. Let Ω\OmegaΩ provide a set of possible steps that we can take toward our destination. Each step’s size is si∈[0,1],s_i \in [0, 1],si​∈[0,1], which means that if you choose to take step i,i,i, you get 100si100 s_i100si​ percent of the way from your current location to the destination.3 If XXX is the set of steps you choose to take, you will make it

g(X)=1−∏i∈X(1−si)g(X) = 1 - \prod_{i \in X} (1 - s_i)g(X)=1−i∈X∏​(1−si​)

of the way to the destination from your starting point. This g(X)g(X)g(X) is just f(X)f(X)f(X) where each pi=0p_i = 0pi​=0 and qi=siq_i = s_iqi​=si​.

The multidimensional Zeno walk: Now, consider a process optimization problem. We have a set Ψ\PsiΨ (indexed by jjj) of goals to achieve, as well as a set Ω\OmegaΩ (indexed by iii) of tasks we can complete in service of the goals. Tasks can advance multiple goals at once. Let vijv_{ij}vij​ denote the effectiveness of task iii against goal j,j,j, meaning that if you engage in task i,i,i, then vijv_{ij}vij​ of (whatever remains of)4 goal jjj will be completed. Each goal is worth tj≥0t_j \geq 0tj​≥0 story points, and goals can be completed fractionally.

We would like to choose the set of tasks XXX that maximizes the team’s velocity in the current planning period, defined as the total number of story points completed, which is

h(X)=∑j∈Ψ(tj−tj∏i∈X(1−vij)).h(X) = \sum_{j \in \Psi} \Bigl( t_j - t_j \prod_{i \in X} (1 - v_{ij}) \Bigr).h(X)=j∈Ψ∑​(tj​−tj​i∈X∏​(1−vij​)).

Tasks are subject to a variety of constraints due to considerations such as cost, scheduling, and dependency. It is not immediately obvious which tasks we should prioritize—for example, should we favor tasks that advance many different goals, or those that have high effectiveness against the most important goals? Well, the jjjth term of h(X)h(X)h(X) is just tjg(X)t_j g(X)tj​g(X) where sss is the jjjth column of vvv. Thus, h(X),h(X),h(X), as a conic combination of submodular functions, is itself submodular,5 and we can compute the optimal velocity using any of the well-known techniques for submodular maximization.

Returning to Zeno’s paradox, the business process described above is akin to a multidimensional Zeno walk in which tjt_jtj​ gives your distance from the target in the jjjth coordinate axis, and each step iii moves you vijv_{ij}vij​ of the way towards the target along that axis. The function h(X)h(X)h(X) measures the one-norm distance between your final position and the target.

Remarks

Linearization: To maximize f(X)f(X)f(X) as written, in typical cases, it will be simplest to minimize 1−f(X),1 - f(X),1−f(X), which is a modular function after taking the logarithm.6 The logarithm trick doesn’t work, however, for conic combinations of f(X)f(X)f(X); the best we can do is introduce helper variables and reformulate the problem as an integer convex program.7 Thus, recognizing the submodularity of f(X)f(X)f(X) (and the strong approximation results implied) is worthwhile.

Serial processes: It is not difficult to show, using a similar proof as above, that the “serial process success probability with quality upgrades” function

f~(X)=∏i∈Ω∖Xpi∏i∈Xqi\tilde f(X) = \prod_{i \in \Omega \setminus X} p_i \prod_{i \in X} q_if~​(X)=i∈Ω∖X∏​pi​i∈X∏​qi​

with pi≤qip_i \leq q_ipi​≤qi​ is monotone and supermodular; that is, −f~(X)- \tilde f(X)−f~​(X) is monotone decreasing and submodular. Note that 1−f~(X)1 - \tilde f(X)1−f~​(X) has the same functional form as the original f(X),f(X),f(X), but the inequality on pip_ipi​ and qiq_iqi​ comes out backwards. This turns back into the original result (that f(X)f(X)f(X) is increasing and submodular) if you interchange the roles of XXX and Ω∖X\Omega \setminus XΩ∖X.

References

Open access:

  • Badanidiyuru, Ashwinkumar and Jan Vondrák. 2014. “Fast Algorithms for Maximizing Submodular Functions.” In Proceedings of the 2014 Annual ACM–SIAM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms, 1497–1514. https://doi.org/10.1137/1.9781611973402.110.
  • Vondrák, Van. 2017. “Submodular Functions.” Lecture 14 from Math 233B: Polyhedral Techniques in Combinatorial Optimization. https://theory.stanford.edu/~jvondrak/MATH233B-2017/MATH233B.html.
  • Wikipedia, s.v. “burndown chart.”
  • Wikipedia, s.v. “submodular set function.”
  • Wikipedia, s.v. “velocity (software development).”
  • Wikipedia, s.v. “Zeno’s paradox.”

Paywall:

  • Chekuri, Chandra, Jan Vondrák, and Rico Zenklusen. 2014. “Submodular Function Maximization via the Multilinear Relaxation and Contention Resolution Schemes.” SIAM Journal on Computing 43, no. 6: 1831–79. https://doi.org/10.1137/110839655.
  • Kulik, Ariel, Hadas Shachnai, and Tami Tamir. 2013. “Approximations for Monotone and Nonmonotone Submodular Maximization with Knapsack Constraints.” Mathematics of Operations Research 38, no. 4: 729–39. https://doi.org/10.1287/moor.2013.0592.
  • Nemhauser, George, Laurence Wolsey, and Marshall Fisher. 1978. “An Analysis of Approximations for Maximizing Submodular Set Functions—I.” Mathematical Programming 14: 265–94. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF01588971.

  1. A set function is called monotone if X⊆YX \subseteq YX⊆Y implies f(X)≤f(Y)f(X) \leq f(Y)f(X)≤f(Y). ↩

  2. This means that if X∗X^*X∗ is the set that maximizes f(X)f(X)f(X) and X~\tilde XX~ is the set produced by the greedy algorithm, we are guaranteed to have f(X~)≥0.632 f(X∗)f(\tilde X) \geq 0.632\,f(X^*)f(X~)≥0.632f(X∗). In practice, the optimality gap is often much narrower. ↩

  3. In the original Zeno walk, each si=12,s_i = \frac{1}{2},si​=21​, and the (supposedly unachievable) “goal” is to reach the destination rather than to get as close as possible to it. ↩

  4. Depending on the context, it may be more appropriate to have tasks advance goals additively—but that would just be a knapsack problem. Here, we are interested in the more difficult case where tasks make diminishing marginal contributions against the goals. One way this arises in real life is when tasks address goals in redundant ways. For example, against the goal “get rid of all the junk in my house,” the tasks “throw away any items not used in the past six months” and “throw away any items that spark fewer than kkk units of joy” may separately elicit a 50 percent reduction in the total junk, but doing both tasks won’t necessarily remove all the junk, because there is some overlap in the junk removed by both operations. ↩

  5. The fact that a conic combination of submodular functions is submodular isn’t mentioned on the Wikipedia article, but it falls right out of the second definition. ↩

  6. A set function is modular if it is both submodular and supermodular. This means that each item’s marginal value is constant—and thus modular functions are equivalent to linear functions of the characteristic vector. The knapsack objective function is an example of a monotone modular function. ↩

  7. Email me if you would be interested in a follow-up post explaining how to do this. ↩
